title: Creation
summary: God creates the universe, earth, plants, animals, and humans in six days and rests on the seventh.
narrative: In majestic, rhythmic language, Genesis 1 portrays God as the sovereign creator who brings order from chaos through his spoken word. With each divine declaration, new aspects of creation emerge in a purposeful sequence, culminating in humanity who bears God's image and is given responsibility to care for creation. The repeated refrain 'and it was good' affirms the inherent value of the created world, while God's rest on the seventh day establishes a pattern for human living.

connections.explanation: John uses similar 'in the beginning' language to connect Jesus as the Word to Genesis creation.
The Psalm references creation by God's word, echoing Genesis 1's repeated 'God said.'
Paul identifies Christ as the one through whom all things were created.

text.kjv: In the beginning God created the heaven and the earth.
text.web: In the beginning, God created the heavens and the earth.

text.kjv: And the earth was without form, and void; and darkness was upon the face of the deep. And the Spirit of God moved upon the face of the waters.
text.web: The earth was formless and empty. Darkness was on the surface of the deep and God's Spirit was hovering over the surface of the waters.

text.kjv: And God said, Let there be light: and there was light.
text.web: God said, "Let there be light," and there was light.

text.kjv: And God saw the light, that it was good: and God divided the light from the darkness.
text.web: God saw the light, and saw that it was good. God divided the light from the darkness.

text.kjv: And God called the light Day, and the darkness he called Night. And the evening and the morning were the first day.
text.web: God called the light "day", and the darkness he called "night". There was evening and there was morning, the first day.
